column4: I couldn't image ██████████████ in a serious role, but his performance truly
I'll admit that I was reluctant to see it because from what I knew of ██████████████ he was only able to do comedy.
The acting is all up to ██████ and he carries his thankless character perfectly.
███████ was a finer draftsman and a brilliant artist at that age than many artists will ever become in a lifetime.
The incredible performance by ██████████ is brilliant and provocative and the editing, sound design, cinematography and directing are truly inspired.
Her Excellency Madam ████████████ has worked in countless movies over life time.

These two genres (i.e. deep meaningful alternative-love story and comic satire) usually mix together just as well as oil and water do, but █████ (somehow) manages to achieve the balance to near perfection.
While developing her primary subject matter, █████ manages to achieve this secondary theme skillfully.
As legend goes, ███ subjugates his wife by making her walk through a Fire to prove her `purity.'
████, in response, cries and leaves him, reuniting with her mother(the Earth).
I guess the fact that so many women applauded ████████'s work, was because it provided them with an option to think for themselves.
Bravo to ████████ in translating her vision so clearly.
I especially like the flashbacks to the young █████ trying to 'see' for the ocean.
The movie is beautifully filmed and enhanced by the musical score by ███████████.
█████████████ "Fire" is groundbreaking, bold, and artistic.
█████████████ music is the work of the genius and almost plays the role of another character in the film.

'Water' (2005), the final part of Toronto-based Indian film-director ███████████'s elemental trilogy has been finally completed, almost ten years after the release of the very first controversial element, 'Fire' (1996), which was followed with a slightly lesser controversial sequel '1947: Earth' (1998).
International fame followed ███████████ in 1996 with the release of the controversial 'Fire', which spread with rage among the false patriotic consciousness existing Indian extremist.
Having already explored friendship between two women in '███████', in 'Fire' Mehta went a step further to portray a more intimate relationship between two lonely neglected women.

Set in modern day India, the suburbs of the capital city of New Delhi, it shows two brothers and their wives, the elder brother (████████████████████) having joined a weird Hindu sect leads a life of celibacy, faithful to his guru of sexless existence.

Two years later, █████████████ second installment was the element of mother earth, released in India by the name of '1947: Earth',yet another excellent movie by a great director, this time in the Hindi language, unlike 'Fire', which was made in the English language.
Now ███████████ has managed to complete the trilogy, despite a lot of problems, having released the final installment recently, 'Water'.
The scene where ███████████ loses her virginity to her husband certainly was the first of its kind in Indian cinemas.
Good acting by all the actors especially ███████████ amidst criticism from the Indian public
I admire ███████████ and this movie is a masterpiece.
████ still cared enough for him to find that moment to let him know that he is not responsible for her deviant outlet to her blocked desires.
But the final act of rejection was by the grandmother - she could not break free from her rusted mindset to accept ████'s desire.
I finally watched the third film in █████'s trilogy: "Fire".
█████ is one brave lady: she sees with a clear eye much that is jaundiced, false and repressive about the great society from which she came from.
Worse, if someone like █████ has the courage to hold up a mirror to these issues, she faces death threats.
█████ is clearly impatient with the totally rigid religious attitudes that either keep widows in misery (Water) or else keep women enslaved to loveless marriages (Fire).
In any case █████'s film is a very moving, powerful attempt at sexual discourse that holds modern Indian relationships up to probing scrutiny.
█████ is forcing the issues to be looked at no matter how much flack.
██████, disturbing, provocative, taboo shattering.
The trailers looked good, but the water theme was giving me bad flashbacks to the last █████████████ movie that dealt with the subject - Waterworld.
Plus, despite the promise ██████████████ showed in The Butterfly Effect, I'm still not completely sold on him.
The movie immediately throws us into the midst of a tense rescue mission, and I was gripped tighter than █████████████ orange face lift.
Sunglasses, a tough guy toothpick in his mouth, and sportin' a smirk that'd make ██████████████ proud?
I had a bad feeling that the pace would slow too much when ███████ started training the young guys, but on the contrary, the training sessions just might be the most interesting aspect of the film.
█████████████ somewhat mis-titled FIRE is the first of a loosely connected trilogy, here linked by the theme of the elements, and more symbolic than consuming.
One husband married a vivacious young woman, ████, out of family obligation.
This arranged marriage is uncomfortable for them both but in the beginning ████ makes an attempt to connect with her sullen husband.
However, he sees himself as a victim and could have cared less about ████--and he continues to have an affair with a liberal-minded Chinese lady.
In their dead marriage, sex was purely meant to produce children and there was no way ████ could have any of her sexual or emotional needs met.
By the way, director ███████████ (a popular female director) has made several other wonderful films such as EARTH and BOLLYWOOD/Hollywood.
This is my first ███████████ film.

█████'s film of two bisexual ladies in an Indian middle-class household may be sacrilege to some, but merely captures the atrophy of middle-class homes that does not seem to aspire for something better than its immediate survival in a limited social space.
Previous reviewer ████████████████ gave a much better recap of the film's plot details than I could.
This intelligent, moving and beautiful film is a study in the ways people react to tradition (reminds me of ██████████████████ novels).
I am happy to say that ██████ is great in this part.
However, the use of humor, the exploration of the toughness of the training and the fun of watching ███████████ "do his own thing as a trainer", kept me riveted and thoroughly entertained.
To my mind, the very character played by ████████████ is a symbol of the Indian feminine protest against the Indian society.
I was impressed with ███████████, who was quite attractive, and played her character with total earnestness.
But I was even more impressed with ████████████, who I understand is a long-time fixture of Bollywood.

Besides the apparent connections with "██████" (and Park-wook's other films), an incestuous relation in this one really disturbed me, and also the subtle erotic theme that hung around all the vampiric, physical action.

Park-wook has really, really mastered his cinematography in this film, and owes a lot to ███████████████; there are a whole lot of beautiful shots strewn throughout the film, some for simple effects and some that require several glances and probably repeated views to fully catch.
████████████████ new film is a complex film that is not easy to classify.
The film takes its own matters and mixes them with classic European literature, in this case ████████████ "Thérèse Raquin".
Although I've never seen the film, I couldn't help but feel like this was ████████████████ version of Twilight.
The psychological aspect that I love about ████'s previous films is in Thirst, as well.
██████████████ bites into the vampire mythology with Thirst and puts his own dark, psychological twist on it.
Anything ██████████████ creates is guaranteed to be unique, brilliant, and very twisted at a minimum.
As negative as it may sound the positives definitely outweigh the negatives and another volume has without a doubt been added to the dark and twisted Zeitgeist of ██████████████ film.
That was not the case when I watched ██████, under the American title Thirst.
There aren't many negatives I can say about ██████.
"bakjwi" literally means bat in korean and we all know that in many classic vampire stories, you see count ███████ or vampires turning into a bat and fly away or wuheva.

Duality of human nature = if you ever read █████'s fables, there is this one fable where mammals and birds are fighting and a bat just can't seem to take a side and it tries to play both sides to his advantage.
██████████████ is a master of cinematography and this movie is no exception.
██████████████ is no stranger to controversy as we know, and this film touches on taboo almost as much as oldboy.

Instead of legitimately dying, █████ becomes a vampire, always yearning for the sustenance blood gives for him to fight off an infectious disease which returns causing the symptoms which flat-lined him to begin with(..bumps/sores, and the body vomits blood).
Sunlight, as is known in the vampire genre, causes torturous death if exposed to █████ for a length of time.
In doing so, █████ has created a monster.
██████████████ throws that concept completely out the window and shows directly what he wants--and what he wants to show is pretty much anything he can think of.
Leaving it to the actors and dialog to create subtlety, from a stylistic perspective ████ seems willing to do just about anything to get his point across.
█████████ adds some much needed humour into the film, but this is only realised in the final third of the movie.
'Thirst' is original, entertaining and fortunately a little less weird than ████████████████ earlier endeavors.
██████████████, you have to hand it to the guy.

Co-star ████████████ (HBO's "Carnivale" - great to see him again) played the captain of the Coast Guard's Kodiak, Alaska base in a strong, convincing role as a leader with the prerequisite and necessary ice water in his veins.

There's nothing terribly weepy or insipid with the story and characters at any point, and the implications put forth from religion early on (████, for example, is seen as a healer of sorts since he rose from the dead thanks to his vampirism, even as he just can't be that and knows it) on top of those about good vs evil, push it up into another plane cinematically.
Korean cinema has the ability to turn genres on its head, and the latest by the celebrated director ██████████████ is a tale of a good pious priest who becomes a vampire.
The mentor this time is played perfectly by █████████████; An ordinary man with common everyday problems who lives an extraordinary conviction, to save lives.
While his scenes with the local love interest are a tad stiff and don't generate enough heat to melt butter, he compliments ███████ well.
Well, I have to disagree with ██████████████ on this animated short.
Director ████████████ offers endless laughters by means of absurd and unexpected demonstrative humour.
It will be the death of ███████████████" Fascinating study on changing an image.
█████ is beautiful and uses her many talents, throughout the film.
Fun, entertaining movie about WWII German spy (█████████████!)
Had to do a double take when I saw that was ███████████ there.
But, overall a great film with a truly outstanding performance by █████████.
Of course, none of this would have been possible if █████████████████████ hadn't written his wonderful play.
